facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1462 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 1462 of 1968. Appeal from the- judgment and order dated November 28, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in appeal from Original Order No. 201 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 28, 1967 of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: judgment and order dated November 28, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in appeal from Original Order No. 201 of 1966. C. Sefalvad, G. L. Mukhoty and D. N. Gupta, for the ap- pellant.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court appeal from Original Order No. 201 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: the Calcutta High Court in appeal from Original Order No. 201 of 1966. C. Sefalvad, G. L. Mukhoty and D. N. Gupta, for the ap- pellant. K. Chatterjee ,for respondents Nos. 2 and 3.

facts.text: Appellant company filed writ petition before Calcutta High Court to quash award by Second Industrial Tribunal directing reinstatement of Ganapati Sontra.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a companypany incorporated under the Comapanies Act, filed a writ petition before the High Court of Calcutta praying for the issue of a writ or an order in the nature of certiorari quashing the award passed by the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, Calcutta, directing the reinstatement of Ganapati Sontra, the second respondent, in the service of- the appellant.

facts.text: Learned single judge of Calcutta High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: A learned judge of that Court dismissed the writ petition. The appellant filed an appeal before a Division Bench of that Court.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal before Division Bench of Calcutta High Court, which was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal before a Division Bench of that Court. The appeal was also dismissed. This appeal is preferred against the order of the Division Bench by certificate granted by the High Court under Article 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal preferred by certificate under Article 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is preferred against the order of the Division Bench by certificate granted by the High Court under Article 133 1  c  of the Constitution. The second respondent was employed by the appellant in the year 1946 as a clerk in its Service Department.

facts.text: Second respondent Ganapati Sontra employed by appellant in 1946 as clerk in Service Department.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent was employed by the appellant in the year 1946 as a clerk in its Service Department. At the time, there was numberrule prescribing the age of retirement of the workmen of the companypany.

facts.text: In 1946, no rule prescribing age of retirement for workmen.

anchor.surface_text: At the time, there was numberrule prescribing the age of retirement of the workmen of the companypany. In November, 1951, the appellant introduced standing orders under the provisions of the Industrial Employment Standing Orders  Act, 1946

facts.text: Appellant introduced standing orders in November 1951 fixing retirement age at 55.

anchor.surface_text: In November, 1951, the appellant introduced standing orders under the provisions of the Industrial Employment Standing Orders  Act, 1946  Central Act 20 of 1946 was amended by the Act 36 of 1956. The Standing Orders fixed at 55.

facts.text: Central Act 20 of 1946 amended on September 17, 1956 by Act 36 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Central Act 20 of 1946 was amended by the Act 36 of 1956. The Standing orders in the appellant companypany were modified on May 30, 1961, but the provision regarding the age of superannuation remained unchanged.

facts.text: Standing orders modified on May 30, 1961, retirement age remained 55.

anchor.surface_text: The Standing orders in the appellant companypany were modified on May 30, 1961, but the provision regarding the age of superannuation remained unchanged. On November 27, 1961, the appellant issued a numberice to the second respondent informing him that he was due to retire on August 31, 1962 as he would be attaining the age of 55 on that date.

facts.text: On November 27, 1961, appellant issued notice to second respondent to retire on August 31, 1962 upon attaining 55.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1961, the appellant issued a numberice to the second respondent informing him that he was due to retire on August 31, 1962 as he would be attaining the age of 55 on that date. On August 11, 1962, respondent No. 3, the Union of the employees of the appellant, submitted a charter of demands.

facts.text: Second respondent attained age of 55 on August 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: informing him that he was due to retire on August 31, 1962 as he would be attaining the age of 55 on that date.

facts.text: On August 11, 1962, respondent No. 3 (Union) submitted charter of demands including raise retirement age from 55 to 60.

anchor.surface_text: On August 11, 1962, respondent No. 3, the Union of the employees of the appellant, submitted a charter of demands. One of the demands was to raise the age of retirement of the workmen in the establishment from 55. to 60.

facts.text: On August 18, 1962, respondent No. 3 wrote to appellant to keep retirement of second respondent in abeyance.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1962, respondent No. 3 wrote to the appellant to keep the retirement of second respondent in abeyance till a decision is arrived at on the charter of demands.

facts.text: On August 30, 1962, second respondent wrote to appellant to postpone decision on retirement.

anchor.surface_text: On August 30, 1962, the second respondent wrote to the appellant to postpone taking a final decision on the matter as a dispute had already been raised about the retirement age of the workmen in the establishment.

facts.text: On August 31, 1962, Secretary of appellant replied that guided by standing orders unless altered.

anchor.surface_text: By his letter dated August 31, 1962, the Secretary of the appellant companypany replied that as long as the retirement age as provided in the stand- ing orders was number altered, he had to be guided by the same but that, if at a later date, the retirement age was altered, the same will be adhered to.

facts.text: Second respondent retired on September 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent was made to retire on September 1, 1962. The Government of West Bengal, by its order dated January 29, 1963, made a reference to the first respondent of the industrial dispute between the appellant and its workmen represented by the third respondent.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred industrial dispute on January 29, 1963 to first respondent (Tribunal).

anchor.surface_text: The Government of West Bengal, by its order dated January 29, 1963, made a reference to the first respondent of the industrial dispute between the appellant and its workmen represented by the third respondent.

facts.text: Reference questions: Is superannuation of Shri Ganapati Santra justified? What relief? What should be age of retirement?

anchor.surface_text: The second question referred, which alone is material for our purpose was Is the superannuation of Shri Ganapati Santra justified ? What relief, if any, is he entitled to ? What should be the age of retirement of the workmen in the factory ?

facts.text: Appellant contended before Tribunal that retirement at 55 per standing orders was proper.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended before the Tribunal on the basis of the standing orders that the age of retirement was 55 years and that the action of the appellant in retiring the second respondent at the age of 55 was proper.

facts.text: Union contended second respondent not bound by standing orders of 1952 or 1961 as employed in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Union, on the other hand, companytended that, as the second respondent was appointed in 1946 when there was numberage fixed for superannuation, he was number bound by the provision as regards the age of superannuation in the standing orders of 1952 or the modified standing orders of 1961.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award dated April 27, 1964: retirement unjustified, direct reinstatement; raise age to 58 for all.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, by its award dated April 27, 1,964, held that the retirement of the second respondent at the age of 55 was unjustified as the second respondent was number bound by the provision in the standing orders of 1952 or of 1961 fixing the age of retirement at 55 as he was employed in the companycern in 1546, and directed reinstatement of the second respondent.

facts.text: Single judge dismissed writ, followed Guest Keen Williams, held not bound, but no reinstatement as age 58 attained, pay salary till 58.

anchor.surface_text: A single judge of the High Court, following the decision of this Court in Guest Keen Williams Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling and others 1  held that the provision as regards the age of retirement in the standing orders would number bind the 2nd respondent as he was employed prior to the companying into force of the standing orders and dismissed the writ petition.

facts.text: Division Bench agreed with single judge and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench agreed with the view of the learned single judge and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Second respondent attained age of 58 by time of High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: He further held that as the second respondent had already attained the age of 58 years, there was numberquestion of his reinstatement

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court view on standing orders not binding pre-employees cannot stand, citing Agra Electric etc.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court that the provision in the standing orders regarding retirement age cannot bind the workmen who were employed in the establishment prior to the companying into force of the standing orders cannot stand in the light of the decisions of this Court in Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Shri Alladin and others  2  , Salem Erode Electricity Disribution Company Ltd. v. Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. Employees Union  3  and the United Provinces Electric Supply Co. Ltd., Allahabad v. T. N. Chatterjee and others 4
Article 133 1  c  of the Constitution

issues.text: whether the view of the High Court, that the provision in the standing orders regarding the age of retirement of the workmen of the appellant company would not govern the 2nd respondent who was employed prior to the coming into force of the standing orders, can be sustained

anchor.surface_text: The only question which should normally arise in this appeal is whether the view of the High Court, that the provision in the standing orders regarding the age of retirement of the workmen of the appellant companypany would number govern the 2nd respondent who was employed prior to the companying into force of the standing orders, can be sustained.

issues.text: whether the award raising retirement age to 58 years would bind the 2nd respondent under section 18(3) of the Industrial Disputes Act even if he was not a workman at the time, as he was employed on the date of the dispute

anchor.surface_text: although the 2nd respondent was not a workman when he was a party to the dispute under s. 18 3  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter called the Act. Counsel submitted that the 3rd respondent, the Union, was a party to the dispute which means that all the workmen in the establishment were parties to the dispute as regards the age of retirement, and the award, in so far as it raised the age of retirement to 58, would bind all persons who were employed in the establishment to which the dispute related on the date of the dispute.

issues.text: whether the award had retrospective operation or conferred benefit of enhanced retirement age only on workers in the establishment on the date the award came into operation under section 17A

anchor.surface_text: the award had no retrospective operation and since the award conferred the benefit of the enhanced age of retirement only on the workers in the establishment on the date the award came into operation and since the 2nd respondent was made to retire in accordance with the retirement age as specified in the standing orders of the companypany and had ceased to be a workman on the date when the award became operative, the award did not confer upon the 2nd respondent any benefit in respect of his age of retirement.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think it necessary to decide the interesting question that in view of the fact that the award became operative only in 1964 whether the 2nd respondent, who was made to retire in 1962 in accordance with the provision in the standing orders then in force, was entitled to get the benefit of the retirement age fixed by the award, on the ground that the award was binding on him and the appellant by Virtue of section 18 3  of the Act.

holdings.text: The view of the High Court that the provision in the standing orders regarding retirement age cannot bind the workmen who were employed in the establishment prior to the coming into force of the standing orders cannot stand in the light of the decisions of this Court in Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Shri Alladin and others, Salem Erode Electricity Disribution Company Ltd. v. Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. Employees Union and the United Provinces Electric Supply Co. Ltd., Allahabad v. T. N. Chatterjee and others.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court that the provision in the standing orders regarding retirement age cannot bind the workmen who were employed in the establishment prior to the companying into force of the standing orders cannot stand in the light of the decisions of this Court in Agra Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Shri Alladin and others

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court view rejected based on binding precedents holding that certified standing orders bind all workmen including those employed prior to certification.

holdings.text: It is not open to this Court, in this appeal, to enlarge the scope of the controversy and go into the question whether the 2nd respondent could sustain the award on any other ground not decided in his favour by the Tribunal or the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: it is not open to this Court, in this appeal, to enlarge the scope of the controversy and go into, the question whether the 2nd respondent could sustain the award on any other ground not decided in his favour by the Tribunal or the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal ordered reinstatement solely on ground that standing orders did not bind pre-existing employee; alternative ground under section 18(3) not raised or decided below; counter-affidavit did not rely on award's enhanced age.

holdings.text: We do not think it necessary to decide the interesting question that in view of the fact that the award became operative only in 1964 whether the 2nd respondent, who was made to retire in 1962 in accordance with the provision in the standing orders then in force, was entitled to get the benefit of the retirement age fixed by the award, on the ground that the award was binding on him and the appellant by virtue of section 18(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think it necessary to decide the interesting question that in view of the fact that the award became operative only in 1964 whether the 2nd respondent, who was made to retire in 1962 in accordance with the provision in the standing orders then in force, was entitled to get the benefit of the retirement age fixed by the award, on the ground that the award was binding on him and the appellant by Virtue of section 18 3  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question left undecided as it would require entertaining new plea not basis of tribunal award or raised below.

holdings.text: It is clear from the award that the Tribunal did not order the reinstatement of the 2nd respondent on the ground that he was entitled to the benefit of the enhanced retirement age conferred on all categories of workers in the establishment by the award. The only ground on which the Tribunal ordered the reinstatement was that the 2nd respondent was employed in the concern prior to the coming into force of the standing orders and, therefore, the provision in the standing orders fixing the age of retirement at 55 was not binding on him.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the award that the Tribunal did number order the reinstatement of the 2nd respondent on the ground that he was entitled to the benefit of the enhanced retirement age companyferred on all categories of workers in the establishment by the award.  The only ground on which the Tribunal ordered the reinstatement was that the 2nd respondent was employed in the companycern prior to the companying into force of the standing orders and, there fore, the provision in the standing orders fixing the age of retirement at 55 was number binding on him in the light of the decision of this Court in Guest Keen Williams Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling and others 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court's analysis of tribunal's reasoning, which is now rejected by h1.

Ltd., Allahabad v. T. N. Chatterjee and others 4

The writ of certiorari provides the jurisdictional basis for the court to examine and issue the holding on the tribunal's award concerning retirement age and reinstatement.

The writ of certiorari is invoked to challenge the tribunal's decision concerning the justification of superannuation, entitlement to relief, and retirement age of workmen, as reflected in the clustered nodes.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the award that the Tribunal did number order the reinstatement of the 2nd respondent on the ground that he was entitled to the benefit of the enhanced retirement age companyferred on all categories of workers in the establishment by the award.  The only ground on which the Tribunal ordered the reinstatement was that the 2nd respondent was employed in the companycern prior to the companying into force of the standing orders and, there fore, the provision in the standing orders fixing the age of retirement at 55 was number binding on him in the light of the decision of this Court in Guest Keen Williams Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling and others 1 .
